issues.text: whether the Parliament has abdicated its legislative function by under section 8(2)(b) of the Act not fixing the rate of central sales tax but adopting the rate applicable to the sale or purchase of goods inside the appropriate State in case such rate exceeds 10 per cent

anchor.surface_text: It has been argued on-behalf of the appellants that the, fixation of rate of tax is a legislative function and as the Parliament has, under section 8 2   b  of the Act, number fixed the rate of central sales tax but has adopted the rate applicable to the sale or purchase of goods inside the appropriate State in case such rate exceeds 10 per cent, the Parliament has abdicated its legislative function.

arguments.claim: section 8(2)(b) of the Central Sales Tax Act suffers from excessive delegation of legislative power because Parliament has not fixed the rate of central sales tax but adopted the rate applicable to sale/purchase inside appropriate State if exceeds 10%

anchor.surface_text: It has been argued on-behalf of the appellants that the, fixation of rate of tax is a legislative function and as the Parliament has, under section 8 2   b  of the Act, number fixed the rate of central sales tax but has adopted the rate applicable to the sale or purchase of goods inside the appropriate State in case such rate exceeds 10 per cent, the Parliament has abdicated its legislative function. The above provision is companysequently stated to be companystitutionally invalid because of excessive delegation of legislative power.

arguments.claim: Section 8(2)(b) enacted to prevent evasion of central sales tax; clear policy that CST rate shall not be less than local rate (min 10%)

anchor.surface_text: Section 8  2   b  of the Act has plainly been enacted with a view to prevent evasion of the payment of the central sales tax. The Act prescribes a low rate of tax of 3 per cent in the case of inter-State sales only if the goods are sold to the Government or to a registered dealer other than the Government In the case of such a registered dealer, it is essential that the goods should be of the description mentioned in sub-section  3  of section 8 of the Act.

Sen appearing for the appellants submitted that Parliament, by enacting s. 8 2  b  has delegated its legislative function to fix the rate of tax leviable on the turnover of sales of goods in the companyrse of inter-State trade companying within the purview of the sub-clause and has abdicated its legislative function in so far as it adopted the rate that might be. fixed in the sales tax law of the appropriate State from time to time for taxing the local sales. Petitions Nos. 191 of 1968, 30 of 1970, 63. and 64 of 1972. ... The High Court answered this question in the negative and upheld the companystitutional validity of those provisions.

holdings.text: section 8(2)(b) of the Central Sales Tax Act does not suffer from the vice of abdication or excessive delegation of legislative power

anchor.surface_text: As a result of the above, we hold that section 8  2   b  of the Central Sales Tax Act does number suffer from the vice of abdication or excessive delegation of legislative power.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Parliament enunciated clear policy to prevent evasion of CST by requiring rate to be 10% or local rate whichever higher, channeling sales through registered dealers; followed State of Madras v. N.K. Nataraja Mudaliar; distinguished B. Shama Rao v. Pondicherry as no total surrender; affirmed delegation doctrine requiring policy/standard which is satisfied

precedents.citation: State of Madras v. N. K. Nataraja Mudaliar 1 1968 3 SCR 829

anchor.surface_text: Dealing with the provisions of section 8 2   b  of the Act, Hegde J. in the case of State of Madras v. N. K. Nataraja Mudaliar 1  observed Then we companye to el.  b  of s. 8  2 , which deals with goods other than declared goods. Here the law at the relevant time was that the tax shall be calculated at the rate of seven percents of the turnover or at the rate applicable to sale or purchase of such goods inside the appropriate State, whichever is higher. As companyld be seen from the report of the Taxation Enquiry Committee, the main reason for this provision was to prevent as far as possible the evasion of sales tax.

precedents.case_name: State of Madras v. N. K. Nataraja Mudaliar
precedents.cited_proposition: Section 8(2)(b) of the Central Sales Tax Act is intended to prevent evasion of sales tax by canalising inter-State trade through registered dealers and does not amount to abdication of legislative function
precedents.cited_holding: The adoption of the rate of local sales tax for central sales tax does not show that Parliament abdicated its legislative function; a definite legislative policy can be discerned

precedents.citation: B. Shama Rao v. The Union Territory of Pondicherry 1 1967 2 SCR 650

anchor.surface_text: There is, in our opinion, marked difference between the enactment of a law which was struck down by this Court in the case of B. Shama Rao v. The Union Territory of Pondicherry 1  and that companytained in section 8  2   b  of the Central Sales Tax Act. In Shama Raos case the Legislative Assembly for the Union Territory of Pondicherry passed the Pondicherry General Sales Tax Act which was published on June 30, 1965.

precedents.case_name: B. Shama Rao v. Union Territory of Pondicherry
precedents.cited_proposition: Pondicherry Sales Tax Act invalid due to total surrender of legislative function to Madras Legislature by adopting its Act as amended after enactment
precedents.cited_holding: The Act was void and still-born; amendment could not revive it as it involved anticipating future amendments by another legislature

precedents.citation: Corporation of Calcutta Anr. V. Liberty Cinema 1 1965 2 SCR 477

anchor.surface_text: It may be stated that this Court in two cases has upheld the validity of statute by which the legislature left the fixation of rates to another body. This was, however, subject to the rider that the legislature must provide guidance for such fixation. In the case of Corporation of Calcutta Anr. V. Liberty Cinema 1  while dealing with section 548 of the Calcutta Municipal Act relating to the levy of licence fee,

precedents.case_name: Corporation of Calcutta v. Liberty Cinema
precedents.cited_proposition: Fixing of rates of taxes may be left to a non-legislative body provided the legislature provides guidance for such fixation

precedents.citation: Pandit Banarsi Das Bhanot The State of Madhya Pradesh 2 1959 SCR 427

anchor.surface_text: after referring to the earlier case of Pandit Banarsi Das Bhanot The State of Madhya Pradesh 2  observed This therefore is clear authority that the fixing of rates may be left to number-legislative body. No doubt when the power to fix rates of taxes is left to another body, the legislature must provide guidance for such fixation.

precedents.case_name: Pandit Banarsi Das Bhanot v. State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: Legislature can leave fixation of rates in taxation laws to executive

precedents.citation: Municipal Corporation of Delhi v. Birla Cotton, Spinning and, Weaving Mills Delhi Anr. 3 1968 3 SCR 231

anchor.surface_text: In Municipal Corporation of Delhi v. Birla Cotton, Spinning and, Weaving Mills Delhi Anr.  3  this Court dealt with the provisions of sections 113 and 150 of the Delhi Municipal Corporation Act in the companytext of levy of certain taxes, including tax on companysumption or sale of electricity.

precedents.case_name: Municipal Corporation of Delhi v. Birla Cotton Spinning and Weaving Mills
precedents.cited_proposition: Delegation of power to fix rates of tax valid if legislative policy and standards are laid down; nature of delegate body is relevant
precedents.cited_holding: Section 150 of Delhi Municipal Corporation Act upheld by majority as not excessive delegation

precedents.citation: Devi Dass Gopal Krishan v. State of Punjab 1 AIR 1967 S.C, 1895

anchor.surface_text: The Constitution, as observed by this Court in the case of Devi Dass Gopal Krishan v. State of Punjab 1  companyfers a power and imposes duty on the legislature to make laws. The essential legislative function is the determination of the legislative policy and its formulation as a rule of companyduct.

precedents.case_name: Devi Das Gopal Krishnan v. State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: Essential legislative function cannot be delegated; policy must be laid down
precedents.cited_holding: Delegation must not lead to self-effacement of legislative power

precedents.citation: In re Delhi Laws Act, 1912. 1 1951 SCR 747

anchor.surface_text: The matter came up for the first time before, this Court In re Delhi Laws Act, 1912.  1  Although each one of the learned Judges who beard that case wrote a separate judgment, the view which emerged from the different judgments was that it companyld number be said that an unlimited right of delegation was inherent in the legislative power itself.

precedents.cited_proposition: Unlimited delegation not permitted; legislature must retain essential legislative function of determining policy and standards

precedents.citation: Harishankar Bagla v. The State of Madhya Pradesh 2 1955 1 SCR 380

anchor.surface_text: In Harishankar Bagla v. The State of Madhya Pradesh 2  this Court dealt with the validity of clause 3 of the Cotton Textile  Control of Movement  Order, 1948 promulgated by the Central Government under section 3 of the Essential Supplies  Temporary Powers  Act, 1946.

precedents.case_name: Harishankar Bagla v. State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: Delegation valid if legislature declares policy and provides standard to guide execution

precedents.citation: Vasantlal- Maganbhai Sanjanwala v. The State of Bombay Ors. 1 1961 SCR 341

anchor.surface_text: In Vasantlal- Maganbhai Sanjanwala v. The State of Bombay Ors.  1  the validity of section 6 2  of the Bombay Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act 67 of 1948 was assailed.

precedents.case_name: Vasantlal Maganbhai Sanjanwala v. State of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: Delegation valid if legislative policy and principles laid down for guidance of delegate

precedents.citation: Sita Ram Bishambhar Dayal Ors. v. State of U.P. Ors., 2 1972 2 SCR 141

anchor.surface_text: In Sita Ram Bishambhar Dayal Ors. v. State of U.P. Ors., 2  this Court observed It is true that the power to fix the rate of a tax is a legislative power but if the legislature lays down the legislative policy and provides the necessary. guidelines, that power can be delegated to the executive.

precedents.case_name: Sita Ram Bishambhar Dayal v. State of U.P.
precedents.cited_proposition: Power to fix tax rates can be delegated if policy and guidelines provided

precedents.citation: Municipal Board, Hapur v. Raghuvendra Kripal 1 1966 1 S.C.R. 950

anchor.surface_text: In Municipal Board, Hapur v. Raghuvendra Kripal 1 , the validity of the U.P. Municipalities Act, 1916, was involved. The Act had empowered the municipalities to fix the rate of tax and after having enumerated the kinds of taxes to be levied, prescribed an elaborate procedure for such a levy and also provided for the sanction of the Government.

precedents.case_name: Municipal Board Hapur v. Raghuvendra Kripal
precedents.cited_proposition: Delegation to municipalities to impose taxes valid given democratic setup and safeguards

precedents.citation: Kathi Ranging Ravat v. State of Saurashtra 3 1952 S.C.R, 435

precedents.case_name: Kathi Raning Rawat v. State of Saurashtra
precedents.cited_proposition: No single principle from Delhi Laws Act case; legislature cannot abdicate essential function

precedents.cited_proposition: Total surrender to another legislature's future amendments invalid

anchor.surface_text: As a result of the above, we hold that section 8  2   b  of the Central Sales Tax Act does number suffer from the vice of abdication or excessive delegation of legislative power. The appeals fail and are dismissed with companyts. One hearing fee.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeals dismissed; section 8(2)(b) of the Central Sales Tax Act, 1956 held constitutionally valid, no excessive delegation.
